data.title: Lost input focus when switching between popup dialogs via shortcut key
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [X ] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Lost input focus when switching between popup dialogs via shortcut key.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. 

Define key maps for dialogs in `keymap.cson`:
```
'body, atom-text-editor':
  'alt-o': 'fuzzy-finder:toggle-buffer-finder'
  'alt-m': 'fuzzy-finder:toggle-file-finder'
```

2.

Press `alt-o` to popup buffer finder, then press `alt-m` to switch to file finder, then the input focus will be lost, and can not press ESC to close the dialog.

### Versions

Atom    : 1.16.0
Electron: 1.3.13
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0
OS: ArchLinux

data.title: Adding an event for Code-Folding to TextEditor class
data.body:
### Description of the Change

This few lines of extra code should add the possibility to manage Code-Folding efficiently. At the time, if you want to develope anything around Code-Folding, the only possibility is to permanently check if a row is folded (with the "isFoldedAtBufferRow()" function).

The problem is: every line inside the block i folded, also gets recognized as folded. So I can't check if maybe a sub-block is also folded

### Alternate Designs

Maybe it would be better to use these events:
onDidFolded
onDidUnfolded

### Why Should This Be In Core?

Because Code-Folding is also very important to many developers and is yet not really integrated.

### Benefits

Easier Package-Development with Code-Folding

### Possible Drawbacks

No drawbacks at all

### Applicable Issues

As it only extends the core, there should not be any issues

data.title: Unbreak URL handlers in Atom 1.17-beta
data.body:
This fixes a regression caused by https://github.com/atom/atom/commit/c4d0944c0da51e0a2d88273ff58a47c469d07be8.

The `urlOpen` function in AtomApplication is still constructing the `PackageManager` in the old way, but we need to use `initialize` now. (Let me know if there is a better way to do this now that we have snapshots!)

Released under CC0.

data.title: Package 的 Keybindings Enable 选项被取消后，Keybindings 栏不见了
data.body:
### Description
我发现一个插件快捷键绑定的问题，当 Package 详情面板的 Keybindings Enable 被取消后，Atom 重启再进 Package 的详情面板时 Keybindings 将会不再显示  
也就是说目前 Package 的 Keybindings 取消了而又关闭了 Atom ，则 Keybindings 无法重新选回来  
如下图所示  

### Steps to Reproduce
1. 初始状态：  
![](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/11657489/25530471/eecd8d3e-2c58-11e7-9ae7-173df8d34684.png)  

2. 取消 Enable 选择：  
![](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/11657489/25530547/34f4b350-2c59-11e7-8d0a-1d6f1b54ede9.png)  

3. 重启 Atom，返回 Package 详情 (Restart Atom，back to package detail)：
![](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/11657489/25530569/49db53fa-2c59-11e7-8b44-e7288e9cbe92.png)  

**Expected behavior:** Keybindings 栏位仍然显示，以便重新启用快捷键  
**Actual behavior:** Keybindings 不见了 (Keybindings is lost)，无法重新启用快捷键  
**Reproduces how often:** 100%

### Versions
Atom v1.16 x64 
(windows10)

### Additional Information  
实际上，Keybindings 还是在的，不过被 display:none 了，但是我觉得这个逻辑应该优化一下，如果插件有申明过快捷键，哪怕被用户取消了，面板应该仍然继续保持显示，以便重新选回

data.title: Minor rendering issue in editor where boxes are drawn around the code
data.body: ### Prerequisites * [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following: * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/ * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages ### Description The div `atom-text-editor .lines` contains many children divs that contain the actual lines of the code being viewed in the editor. Strangely enough, I am seeing funky background colour behaviour here. Here's a screenshot: So I went into the dev tools and checked out what is going on. Turns out each of the children divs's background colour only stretches to a bit past the line where the last character of code in that block is: Now, this is the Seti UI theme and One Dark syntax, but I see it with any combination of ui/syntax themes. Here is the same issue, but in Safe Mode: Now, here's the interesting part - I have tracked down where this actually happens. The culprit is this CSS rule that overwrites the background for each of those containers of code lines: Before you say "@mtimofiiv, this is a theme problem, go ask them about it", **note that it does happen with all themes** and that **toggling this CSS rule on/off in the dev tools actually fixes the problem**, but only for that one block and only temporarily. Unless I am wrong, it seems like a rendering issue. ### Steps to Reproduce I am not sure what I am doing that perhaps others are not. I have a stock install of Atom which is up to date and even in Safe Mode I am seeing this, so it's not a plugin problem as far as I'm aware. I have not modded my config in any crazy way. **Expected behavior:** I expect the background colour of the code blocks to not have jagged box edges. **Actual behavior:** See above **Reproduces how often:** Always. ### Versions Here is the output of `atom --version`: ``` Atom : 1.16.0 Electron: 1.3.13 Chrome : 52.0.2743.82 Node : 6.5.0 ``` And `apm --version`: ``` apm 1.16.1 npm 3.10.5 node 6.9.5 x64 python 2.7.13 git 2.11.0 ``` My OS is macOS Sierra 10.12.3.

data.title: Atom doesn't save the file tree upon closing the program
data.body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [ x  ] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Atom doesn't save the file tree upon closing the program. The ```application.json``` file clears every time, even with **"Restore Previous Windows on Start"** enabled. I have tried completely wiping and re-installing Atom, choosing a different directory, opening it in safe mode, none of those things have solved the issue.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open Atom
2. Open a repository/directory
3. Close Atom
4. Reboot
5. Yield result of a blank editor **insert sad face**

**Expected behavior:** After closing atom, it **should** save my previous project file tree. It doesn't.

**Actual behavior:** Atom opens with a completely blank editor.

**Reproduces how often:** 100% of the time.

### Versions

```
Atom    : 1.16.0
Electron: 1.3.13
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0
```
### Additional Information

I am on the latest version of macOS.

data.title: Is there any event fired when a dock item has been moved?
data.body:
I would like to know when a dock item has been moved to another dock to set an appropriate tooltip placement, but I couldn't find any event to realize this.
I also tried `atom.workspace.getLeftDock().onDidAddPaneItem()` (for the left dock) but it is only fired when a new dock item is added, not when an existing item is moved.

Could you tell me which event subscription I should use, or some other solution?
Thanks.

### Versions
```
Atom    : 1.17.0-beta4
Electron: 1.3.15
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0
```

data.title: Recalculate Tooltip positions when their contents change
data.body:
### Description of the Change

This PR implements `Tooltip#recalculatePosition` which resets the Tooltip's position based on its current size. It also adds a `MutationObserver` that watches for the tooltip to change and calls the aforementioned method on the next animation frame when it does.

### Alternate Designs

`ResizeObserver` is not available until Electron 1.6 (with a flag), so a `MutationObserver` covers the majority of the important use cases until then.

I originally implemented this so the resizing operation took place in an `atom.views.pollDocument` call, but this made the tooltip feel very jerky, so I put it in an rAF instead. Happy to hear other 💭 s.

/cc @nathansobo

data.title: Atom Crashes on Windows 10 Loading 1MB Log Files
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [ ] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    *[X] Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    *[X] Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    *[X] Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    *[X] Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    *[X] Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Atom slows down dramatically and eventually crashes. Tried safe-mode, and was able to reproduce this issue. Tried to clear saved state, and while that did solve the issue temporarily, it did come back. I only have two log files that I am working through, both are about 800kbs and 20k lines (not sure if loc is proper term here).

I have checked for updates after clearing saved state, and it states that 1.16.0 is the latest. Tried to install package-cop, but atom crashed before I even got to that.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Load atom (various conditions: safe mode, clear saved state, etc)
2. Wait or load log files.
3. Wait for Microsoft to say that it is not responding

**Expected behavior:** Smooth operation and scrolling through the log files

**Actual behavior:** Scrolling stops at some point, and atom crashes

**Reproduces how often:** 100%

### Versions

You can get this information from copy and pasting the output of `atom --version` and `apm --version` from the command line. Also, please include the OS and what version of the OS you're running.

Atom    : 1.16.0
Electron: 1.3.13
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0

### Additional Information

[operation_log.txt](https://github.com/atom/atom/files/959570/operation_log.txt)

data.title: Code on line wrapping back and forth at same pace as cursor blinking
data.body:
Hi team, not sure what package repository to file this issue, so I've just made a recording hoping you can point me in the right direction or shed some light on this behaviour:

https://www.dropbox.com/s/lpkybtzkarehyla/madness.gif?dl=0

Focussing the cursor on the affected line caused it to start dancing at about triple the frequency, but that's not visible in the recorded GIF's as the frame rate is too low.

Widening the editor window caused the dancing to stop.

This was experienced with Atom 1.17.0-dev-4a1f98c on OS X.

data.title: 'Save' for a new file should open within the current project directory
data.body:
When creating a new file with Ctrl+N and later saving this file the save dialog starts somewhere within my 'recently used' directory so I need to go through the hassle of navigating to the project directory.

It would be a great thing if the save dialog starts in the current project directory as it is to expected that I want to save it anywhere down there. In really seldom situations I want to save the file outside of the project directory (e.g. in the /tmp directory for a test or so).

I think of this as a bug more then a feature or improvement as it breaks my work flow.

This is what I personally thing. Can't speak for others.
I would appreciate it if this is an option to toggle.

data.title: Feature Request: Always discard project state when "Restore Previous Windows On Start" is false.
data.body:
### Prerequisites
* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description
Hey Atomizers! I wanted to kick a little feature request your way, if it's not too much trouble. I've noticed that in the beta build of Atom, reopening a project in a window with a preexisting tab gives one the option to discard Atom's autosaved project state. I was wondering if it wouldn't be more consistent with the "Restore Previous Windows on Start" setting if, when "restore windows" was flagged `false`, opening any project---from the menu, via drag-and-drop, from the CLI, from a project management package---automatically dropped its state on the floor.

I'm ultimately trying to get back to a world like the one I enjoyed when setting `hot_exit` to `false` in Sublime Text, wherein projects never remember expanded directories or opened tabs. (Unsaved buffers are another story: losing those was a part of the deal with Sublime, but Atom's behavior could in theory be gentler there.) Nineish times out of ten, rather than dropping me helpfully where I was working six minutes ago, the state restoration drops me annoyingly where I was working six weeks ago; it's easier just to get back to where I was on my own.

The behavior is _so close_ to what I'm looking for in `1.17.0-beta3`, _except_ that reopening a project in a clean window always restores its tabs (which focus themselves in the Tree View as I close them, ack):

![screenflow](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2207980/25434235/84b25d5e-2a59-11e7-9d2e-4a45d685fadc.gif)

Can't imagine this being super-high-priority by any stretch, but I also don't quite have the Atom-fu to tackle it on my own. Would be grateful if someone looking for an easy PR would consider it. :pray:

### Steps to Reproduce
1. Open a whole mess'a tabs in an Atom project window.
2. Close the project without explicitly closing your tabs.
3. Open a new window and reopen that selfsame project.
4. Tabs. Why did it have to be tabs.

**Suggested behavior:** When "Restore Previous Windows on Start" is disabled, Atom should discard all preexisting project state---including opened tabs.

**Actual behavior:** Atom selectively remembers some preexisting project state regardless of the setting---including opened tabs.

**Reproduces how often:** 100%

### Versions
```
❯ atom --version
Atom    : 1.17.0-beta3
Electron: 1.3.14
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0
```

```
❯ apm --version
apm  1.17.0
npm  3.10.5
node 6.9.5 x64
python 2.7.13
git 2.12.2
```

```
❯ system_profiler SPSoftwareDataType
Software:

    System Software Overview:

      System Version: macOS 10.12.4 (16E195)
      Kernel Version: Darwin 16.5.0
      Boot Volume: Macintosh HD
      Boot Mode: Normal
      Computer Name: Zbornak
      User Name: Daniel P. Shannon (daniel)
      Secure Virtual Memory: Enabled
      System Integrity Protection: Disabled
      Time since boot: 1 day 12:19
```

### Additional Information
💖

data.title: Re-prioritize @windowForPaths and currentWindow
data.body:
### Description of the Change

Currently, @windowForPaths() being non-null inhibits addToLastWindow, thus rendering the -a switch at least partially useless on ArchLinux with XFCE/Gnome desktop. The patch restores its claimed ability to open documents in an Atom window the user was last working with.
The fix leaves existingWindow equal to @windowForPaths() only if there are no windows more suitable to become an existingWindow.

### Alternate Designs

No alternate designs were considered, as the one in this PR is the least invasive. Here\`s the only place in the whole Atom codebase where addToLastWindow value is actually used.

### Why Should This Be In Core?

This is a bugfix.

### Benefits

Restoration of documented functionality.

### Possible Drawbacks

Calling currentWindow.hasProjectPath(), isFile?() and isDirectory?() for all opened entries even if @windowForPaths() is non-null.

### Applicable Issues

https://stackoverflow.com/questions/43526384

I'm trying to build the 32 bits .deb package.
And I get an error during the snapshot generation using Electron.
(1260)Error: /home/ghost/Temp/atom/out/app/node_modules/rimraf/node_modules/glob/glob.js
Cannot replace with lazy function because the supplied node does not belong to an assignment

### Steps to Reproduce

**Expected behavior:** generating the snapshot, then the .deb package

**Actual behavior:** Error when generating snapshot

**Reproduces how often:** Everytime !

### Versions

atom : v1.18.0
node : v6.10.2
npm: v4.5.0
node-gyp: v3.6.0

### Additional Information

Yes, I'm trying to build the 32bit package.
I still have an old eeePC that works under debian and, while it's not a race computer, I'still using it to write some code...

data.title: Per-package transpilation overhead
data.body:
### Description

Utilizing per-package transpilation brings in some overhead from core dependencies being loaded.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Have a package utilizing per-package transpilation
2. Profile activation
3. Note Atom core dependencies being counted as part of the package activation

#### Expected behavior

Per-package transpilation to have similar overhead to the built in transpilation, assuming the transpiled files are already cached.

#### Actual behavior

A few dependencies are loaded in Atom core, counting against the package's "activation time" in TimeCop.

#### Reproduces how often

100% of the time.

### Versions

```
Atom    : 1.17.0-beta3
Electron: 1.3.14
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0
```

Windows 10 x64

### Additional Information

Here is an example profile taken from a load of https://github.com/AtomLinter/linter-eslint/pull/890/commits/9096fe131d20ad281de1b548b11d55c43b014918:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/427137/25403755/428695a0-29b2-11e7-993e-d975012ce196.png)

The total time for `compileFileAtPath` in this trace is 28.9 ms.

Tracing things down it looks like `minimatch` isn't included in the snapshot (and thus being loaded here) due to https://github.com/atom/atom/pull/14096. Loading that in accounts for 7.8 ms of the time.

The other large require in `getTranspilerPath` looks to be bringing in the `resolve` module [here](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/f4cfe7603fbe99c8f717eb92fdff20d33b3fd90a/src/package-transpilation-registry.js#L154), at least it looks to match the pattern in [that file](https://github.com/substack/node-resolve/blob/5f6e682396eca043624d0a13286b9015b1e6cfce/index.js).

Tagging @BinaryMuse and @as-cii here at the request of @BinaryMuse 😉.

data.title: Atom tree view not working
data.body:
Tree view not working in beta3 1.17 

OS: ubuntu 16.04

Steps to reproduce 
1) Start the Atom editor
2) Open tree view 
3) Expand the folders 
4) First time will work 
5) if you going for next next time, then it will take long time to respond
